title: Playing the game out is no longer a good strategy
body: If you're behind, playing it out only makes it worse. Objectives are so important now that the enemy team can gain piles of gold simply by taking objectives. Now I think objective control is very important, but comebacks are almost impossible when the entire game is based around whoever can salvage a strong enough lead to take objectives easily. No longer can you sit back and farm it out, their lead will grow stronger by just them taking turrets.

I completely disagree with you. It varies wildly depending on several factors. You're oversimplifying a huge and complex issue. One thing I will say is that I think it needs to be harder for a single BAD player to tank a game. That's the biggest issue right now. Here is everything that affects "playing it out": 

- Player skill on your team. 
- Player skill on your best scaling champion (usually the marksman!) 
- Player skill on the enemy team.
- Player skill on the enemies best scaling champion! 
- Champion Choices - Which team scales better?
- Teamfight potential (Who has more CC/Tanks, usually - but which team can win a teamfight?) 
- Vision control and warding prowess

It's rare that a team getting a decent lead to lose, and that's  because one player on the losing team knows how to lead and what to do, has the champion to do so, which means he is better than all of them.

For example, when I play Sivir on my smurf, I know I can win all games, because I know how to stall and get my items, even before the enemy snowballing team does. I can get like 300 cs at 26 minutes, even without having any kills, while the enemy ADC gets like 180. This difference is big enough to guarantee that I can do SOMETHING about the game.

But this is a case on my smurf. It rarely happens in plat 3. As you said, if a team snowballs, it's mostly because the gold lead is big, but it's also because the enemy team is just better.
